text:
Hi all,
I am trying to get the non-interactive login to work following the instructions on Betfair: <https://betfair-developer-docs.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/1smk3cen4v3lu3yomq5qye0ni/pages/2687915/Non-Interactive+bot+login>.
I managed to generate my SSL keys, and I am in the process of testing them using postman. I keep getting the response "ACCOUNT_PENDING_PASSWORD_CHANGE".
According to the guide this means I need to do a password recovery following a given link. I have done this and keep getting the same response. Any ideas?
I have encoded the username and password using this: <https://www.base64encode.org/>
Thanks for the support!

attachments.fallback: Base64 Encode: Base64 Encode and Decode - Online
attachments.text: Encode to Base64 format or decode from it with various advanced options. Our site has an easy to use online tool to convert your data.

text: Log into the account via the website and it should prompt you to change the password

text:
Hi all, noob here. Still able to bypass the £299 fee for live API Key (with the help from Liam/Slack group) or is it a case of paying the fine? 

Cheers

and find out?

text: OK but why base64 encoded and not URL encoded?

elements.text: OK but why base64 encoded and not URL encoded?

text:
I don't know... I assumed you'd want to avoid having your password sent in a readable format.
I've now tried just URL encoding both and it gave me "CERT_AUTH_REQUIRED"

elements.text: I don't know much about that stuff tbh, I've been doing a lot of try and error.

text: I don't know anything about Postman but I would hope that if you choose to use the mime type x-www-form-urlencoded that it will do the encoding for you. In other words: use the plain text values for username and password

elements.text: I don't know anything about Postman but I would hope that if you choose to use the mime type x-www-form-urlencoded that it will do the encoding for you. In other words: use the plain text values for username and password

text: That's a fair shout. Not knowing what is the standard, I assumed base64 might be what they meant with "You should ensure that your username and password values are encoded before being sent to the API; if your password contains special characters and isn't encoded, the login request will fail with CERT_AUTH_REQUIRED/INVALID_PASSWORD"

elements.text: That's a fair shout. Not knowing what is the standard, I assumed base64 might be what they meant with "You should ensure that your username and password values are encoded before being sent to the API; if your password contains special characters and isn't encoded, the login request will fail with CERT_AUTH_REQUIRED/INVALID_PASSWORD"

text:
I have tried putting everything in plain text with no avail.
Apparently there is an email address from betfair for support with API. Any chance they'd be able to help?

text: "paying the fine"? Lifetime access for £300 is an absolute bargain.   I could have got a freebie but fairness deserves respect so I paid it.

elements.text: "paying the fine"? Lifetime access for £300 is an absolute bargain.   I could have got a freebie but fairness deserves respect so I paid it.

text: More a figure of speech but was just trying my luck asking, no harm I suppose…. fully agree £299 for lifetime access is a bargain

elements.text: More a figure of speech but was just trying my luck asking, no harm I suppose
. fully agree £299 for lifetime access is a bargain

text: :+1: 'noob' can mean new here or new to the industry.  Sounds like you already know the difference between price and value. All the best.

elements.text: 'noob' can mean new here or new to the industry.  Sounds like you already know the difference between price and value. All the best.

text: Noob here (and will likely be for sometime!)

elements.text: Noob here (and will likely be for sometime!)

text: £299 can be steep for some (not saying it is for <@U011AN6GPK6>) - e.g. when I was a student, £299 totally put me off doing any API stuff unfortunately (although I got around it by taking an approach that didn't require live market-data, since you can still bet with the delayed key, or at least you could back then). I get that BF need a way to prevent the key from being used just for data-collection, but there must be a way to provide keys for honest customers (and what could result in more liquidity for everyone, comission for BF etc). People often say "if you're not willing to put up £299 you're not gonna make it anyway", but that doesn't sound right - you can make a good profit with even half of that size of investment.

text: Utterly incomprehensible to me why you would pay the fee when you don't have to. Flutter is a multinational behemoth, it doesn't need your charity

text: "must be a way to provide keys for honest customers..."... via Liam.

text: Nothing to do with charity <@UBS7QANF3>, just my principals.

elements.text: Nothing to do with charity
, just my principals.

text: I was a bit mystified when I learned that they introduced a sign up charge for the API after so many years of being free, as it feels like a deterrent to new players. It's easy to say £299 is not much money once you've been profitable for a few years but I bet there are a lot of people who have coughed up that money and not made it back. I get they don't want people scraping for free, but they could have kept it free and just given people a grace period after which you get it revoked if you are not actively putting money in the markets.

elements.text: I was a bit mystified when I learned that they introduced a sign up charge for the API after so many years of being free, as it feels like a deterrent to new players. It's easy to say £299 is not much money once you've been profitable for a few years but I bet there are a lot of people who have coughed up that money and not made it back. I get they don't want people scraping for free, but they could have kept it free and just given people a grace period after which you get it revoked if you are not actively putting money in the markets.

text: <@UUE6E1LA1> I wouldn't be surprised it most people who paid it haven't made it back. It requires a lot of good fortune to find a working strategy.

text: I expect the fee is intentional friction. They've probably had a problem of freeloading API users popping up with new accounts every time one gets shutdown. This would also explain why they're willing to let known users 'vouch' for someone new and forgo the fee
